name: Police Surgeon
description:
The players each take the part of a Police Surgeon and attempt to help people in trouble at various points on the board. Each successful arrival at an emergency earns the Police Surgeon points and the first to accumulate 100 points wins. Game strategy involves gathering the most points while taking into consideration distance to the emergencies, their point value and the likelihood of the emergency cards being returned to the deck. 3 emergency cards are always face up, but one is exchanged from the deck when players land on a red dot. Green Fate spaces require a player to draw a Fate card and follow directions, but may be held to use at an appropriate time if indicated on the card.

Based on a syndicated TV show from 1970's.

name: Balancing Clown
description: A clown is balanced on the high wire between two players. Spin the spinner to dictate the movement of the clown. The object is to move the clown to the opposite side of the wire. Knock down your opponents flag to win the game.

name: Dexter's Laboratory: Race to the Brainergizer!
description:
Players spin a spinner to move their Dexter along the board, taking actions dependent on where they land (drawing an action card, picking up Dee-Dee, grabbing the lab wrench, and some others). Dee-Dee slows down a player, but the lab wrench will let a player counteract any negative effect, including having to take her along.

For Ages 6 and up.

name: Darkies in the Melon Patch
description:
Fake Early Americana Snakes and Ladders style game depicting misrepresented stereotypical images of Blacks in the 30's. Reach the end space first by rolling a die and avoiding pitfall spaces.

There is evidence that this game is not an authentic piece of Black Americana, but instead a counterfeit facsimile. Please see the evidence in this thread: Darkies in the Melon Patch: Disquieting and Inconvenient

name: Chicken Soup for the Teenage Soul II The Game
description: Chicken Soup Teenage, The Game Soul II is an adventure of Sharing, Friendship, and Laughter.Based on the New York Times bestselling books that teenagers treasure, bring you this new edition of the game of real life experiences and surprises! Players share their opinions, stories, and secrets as they answer new questions about issues that are important to them such as friends, lifestyle, and aspirations. They even learn a little something about themselves, which can provide the games most flavorful ingredients and moments.

name: Tele-Fun
description:
This game was produced by Market Force Communications for AT&T Information Systems - it was designed as a training tool for their sales force on the features of the Merlin Communications System (office phones).

The game features an unusual mechanic - each player has two pawns, one which moves on an outer track and one which moves through the players' "offices" (rows of spaces in the center of the board). On a turn a player throws two dice and uses one for each pawn. Moving around the outside track can give you various cards, cartridges (upgrades for your phone system), etc. Moving through the offices gives orders (money/VP) to the player whose office gets landed on.

The object is to have the highest level of Merlin system and get 50 orders. Players need to cash in orders to upgrade from the lower-level systems, and the better your system the more orders your office produces.

The game came in two formats - a standard boxed game and a punch-out version in a large envelope.

name: Walhall
description:
In the Box (Tube):
7 wooden Playingstones in 7 colors
3 wooden Biddingsticks
3 Dice W6
Board (Imitation Leather)
Rules
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling

name: Foresight
description:
Foresight is a challenging game of strategy and chance for two to four players, played with up to 60 five-color chips. You set up the board by rolling the dice and putting the appropriate number of chips in each column. Every game begins differently! Take turns removing chips from columns, using strategy and foresight to force your opponent into picking up the last chip remaining on the board. Whoever picks up the last chip loses.

This game is Nim with randomized starting position

name: Humpty Dumpty
description: Each player, in turn, removes a brick from the wall. Once a player starts to remove a brick, he must continue removing the same brick even though it causes Humpty Dumpty to fall. The player causing Humpty Dumpty to fall is eliminated from the game. The remaining players rebuild the wall, Humpty Dumpty is put back on the wall again and play continues as before. The last player remaining in the game is the winner.

name: Campbell's Alphabet Scoop & Spell
description: Campbell's Scoop and Spell is a word game for 1,2,3, or 4 players. The play consists of forming words directly on a player's own colored place mat. Each player competes for high score by making as many words as possible with the plastic letters scooped from the 'soup can' container. Includes 4 place mats, 216 letters, 4 scoops and 1 score pad.

name: Thunder Ball
description: Thunder Ball is "The Game of Jammin' Hoops and Explosive Magic." A limited number of points are assigned various player skills - Shoot, Steal, Catch, Block and Intelligence - and then the NBA meets Harry Potter and arena combat in a fantasy basketball game to 10 points (five successful shots on the basket of your color on the hexagonal mapboard). Players are allowed two actions per turn with die rolls (augmented by player skill points) determining the success of actions ranging from shooting for a basket to using spell cards.
mechanics: Area Movement, Pick-up and Deliver, Variable Player Powers

name: ITV Seven
description:
For the famous Saturday afternoon sports programe 'World of Sport'
A great game of betting on the horses. Seven races and you bet on the all the one with the most money wins.
You draw 7 cards form a stanard pack and odds are worked out from the 7 cards (chart in the box shows the odds based on the cards). Player bet on one of the four siuts depending on the odds. Cards are trun over one at at time from the pack and for each suit turned over the horse one one place forward. First horse across the line wins.
Easy to play and great fun for 2 to as many as you like.

name: Golden Trivia Cards: National Football League Edition
description:
NFL themed trivia game from the mid-80's. Be sure you know your NFL facts to get these questions correct.


What is Miami's home stadium?
Who is the Colts' all-time rushing leader?
Name three 1983 NFL coaches who were former NFL quarterbacks.
What Super Bowl was the first played on artificial turf?
Name two of the three players who have scored six touchdowns in a game.


These are samples of some of the questions. Just remember when you play... the game was published in 1984.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Memory, Sports, Trivia

name: Junction
description:
"Which pin will connect the circuit and turn on the alarm? Its always a surprise with this changeable circuitry game Wired for excitement and suspense for the whole family." (From the box)

Contains a plastic board with 8x6 grid of holes and hidden electrical circuits and 22 metal hoops for dropping into the board to connect the circuit.

name: All My Children Fact or Fantasy Question Card Game
description:
It's up to you to figure out what's Fact and what's Fantasy!

Since 1970, a lot has happened in the not-so-sleepy town of Pine Valley. Millions of fans tune in to All My Children daily to share in the unexpected happenings -- the romance, the relationships, the real issues that touch everyone's lives. The Fact or Fantasy game gives you a chance to show what you know from All My Children's 28 award winning years... See what you can remember!

Be the first player to collect 5 cards by correctly choosing the one event on each card that DID NOT happen in an episode of All My Children.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: Spongebob Squarepants Big Easy Game
description:
Who's hungry for a Krabby Patty? SpongeBob SquarePants and his pals are! They are eager to collect as many colorform Krabby Patties as they can and race to reach the treasure chest full of gold! Now you can help the nautical crew roam around Bikini Bottom, making snacks along the way, adding or losing Krabby Patties at each destination. 

Barnacles! You've just run into Plankton! Off to The Chum Bucket you go, where you lose a bunch of your Krabby Patties, causing plankton to laugh with glee. He is now one step closer to discover the secret recipe to Krabby Patties! 

Gather as many colorform Krabby Patties as you can and reach the treasure before everyone else. Should you make your way toward Sandy’s dome, or take the path to Patrick’s rock? Don’t worry if you get sidetracked along the way, someone else could get sidetracked too. And if you lose tons of Krabby Patties, just make your way toward Krusty Krab and gather more. 

Who will get to the treasure first--SpongeBob, Patrick, Sand or Squidward? Larger than a regular game board, the super-size play mat is perfect for young ones! 

More than just sailorific good times, this game reinforces important learning skills like counting, color matching, critical thinking and decision-making. It’s seaworthy adventure that your kids will love playing over and over!
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Animotrax
description: Educational game for 1 to 6 children. The players roll a die and move their counters to get to specific areas where endangered species live. They try to match the animals and their babies while answering questions about threats to the environment

name: Trap Surprise
description:
The player, who finds and keeps all their stones first, wins.
The first player removes one of 25 covers. This cover remains aside until the end of the game. Under this lid the player discovers either a stone of his own colour or a coulor of another player or an empty trap. If it is their own colour the player removes the stone and makes another movement until the first player finds a stone of the opponent.

name: Camp Granada
description: In turn, players move the toy Camp Granada Bus as far as they wish. If the bus breaks down, however, the player’s turn is over. The object of the game is to collect three "Icky Animals" and exit Camp Granada. The game is based on “Hello Muddah, Hello Fadduh,” a novelty song of the 1960s. The game comes with the Camp Granada game board, 4 cardboard bunk houses, a plastic Camp Bus, 12 rubber "Icky Animals" (2 each Crawfish, Frog, Lizard, Mouse, Snake, Spider), 16 Icky Animal cards (2 for each of the six animals, plus 4 for the Boating, Bunkhouse, Handicrafts, and Hiking Awards), and 48 "Camp Granada Bus" cards (6 SPECIAL PRIVILEGE, plus 3 for each of 12 of the locations and only 2 for First Aid Training, Bunk House, & Hospital).

name: Last Car, the Game of the Energy Crisis
description:
In "Last Car", the object of the game is to complete a eight-stop shopping trip around the board. Each player starts with a Gas Guzzler that can only move a limited distance before needing more gas. The gas stations on the board, however, only open for brief periods, and stay open only until one of the cars at the pump draws the Last Car card.

If a car runs out of gas, the player can push his car one space at a time to a gas station. Otherwise, movement and fuel consumption are determined by the number of dice thrown.

Players have the opportunity to upgrade their vehicles to more energy efficient ones during the course of the game. These cars are slower (fewer movement dice) and have movement restrictions, but minimize the need to get gas. A player can also opt to stop off at home and switch to a bicycle. This needs no gas but requires the player to roll only one movement die, forgo the expressway, and go home to drop off goods after visiting only two stores.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Houston In A Box
description: Yet another version of monopoly from Late For The Sky; this version is based on Houston, Texas. It has spaces such as the Astrodome, Space Center Houston, Orange Show, Livestock Show & Rodeo, Ninfa's, NASA, and the Alley Theatre. Cards reflect the atmosphere of Houston, as well as certain famous historical events.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: The Green Hornet Quick Switch Game
description:
Based on the TV show. This is a standard roll & move game, typical of the era.

Players can also use a ‘quick switch’ move, which enables them to trade places with their opponents.

name: Chatitude
description: This a kids game where you get asked a question from a card and then input one of three answers into the electronic chat-o-matic game unit. The other players then try to guess your answer based on how well they know you.

name: WineLovers' Challenge
description:
This game does not require any special skills or knowledge. Everyone participates in unlocking the personality of the wine they're tasting. Wine lovers from beginners to expert enjoy playing this party game. It is the world's first and only game that covers the range of the wine appreciation factors including the food matching potential of the wine being tasted. Plus you will also discover wine facts and trivia every time you play our wine tasting game.

The game stimulates sociable conversations on the world of wine and even topics like song lyrics and movie dialogs. If you are looking for fun adult party games, our game is ideal when friends drop in or when planning a wine tasting party.

name: Skicker Football
description:
Same rules as Subbuteo, but you play with cardboard disks on a cardboard field.
It comes with the faces of the players of various teams.
Italian edition only ?

name: Pooh
description:
From the box:
Winnie the Pooh has run out of Hunny. Help your best loved Pooh characters -- Eeyore, Tigger, Rabbit, and Owl -- surprise Pooh by collecting Hunny pots for him. But beware of the bees... they want their Hunny back! (21 disks are hunny pots, 7 are bees). The player that collects the most Hunny pots at the end of the game wins.

This game comes with a Gigantik playmat, 2 1/2 feet x 3 feet big (approx.).
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Masterbrain
description: John Bull were famous in the UK as makers of toy printing sets. Mastermind is a notoriously difficult quiz presented by the BBC. Put them together and you get a very cheap and nasty home quiz, apparently endorsed by the beeb. What is the opposite of acid? Alkali. I've started so I'll finish.

name: Addition Matching Caps
description:
Addition Matching Caps is a memory game with a mathematics theme.

The 48 tokens consist of 23 addition problems, 23 number tokens (answers) and two wild cards. Players turn up two tokens per turn. If the tokens represent an addition problem and the correct answer, the player keeps them and scores one point. There is an "advanced" game in which the object is to not end up with the wild card tokens.

name: Kar-Zoom
description:
This is a simple race car game (predating PitchCar by decades) that's played by shooting wooden disks through an illustrated race course built inside its box. The rectangular box is 19.5" long and about as wide as a cribbage board. At one end is a start circle where the disks are placed at the start of a turn. A straight "racetrack" leads from the circle to the other end of the box, while a cardboard partition zigzags from side-to-side up the length of the box separating it into scoring areas (valued from 1-7). The partition has holes in it, illustrated to look like bridges, where it crosses the track.

On a turn, a player places his disk on the start circle and flicks it as straight as possible down the track. The farther down the track it goes, the more points the player scores. Points are recorded on pegboards along the edge of the box. The first player to score 20 points takes the checkered flag.

name: The Incredible Hulk 3-D Rampage Board Game
description:
Players travel through a multi-level laboratory collecting pieces for a Probe device. The entire board, however, will start to shake with The Hulk's fury at any moment, scattering pieces everywhere.

The shaking is caused, not electronically, but by something they call a "Rage-O-Matic Shaking Mechanism".

name: Stockbroker
description:
Each player has a secret identity decided by random card draw. Identities include Industrial Tycoon, Leisure Tycoon, Newspaper Tycoon etc.

The object of the game is to collect 18 share certificate cards relating to your secret identity e.g. oil shares for the oil tycoon. Other cards include wild cards, stock market drop & rise cards, big bang cards (challenge cards) and gold cards.

The winner is the player who covers all 18 spaces on his game card or is the only player left after all his opponents are out of the game.

name: Stump the Stars
description:
Stump the Stars is basically a copy of the popular party game Charades, but uses jokes and gag categories rather than the standard titles.

Example: “He crossed a carrier pigeon with a porcupine so it could pin the note on the door.” This is a faithful adaptation of the television series also known as Pantomime Quiz.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Word Game

name: The Wizard of Oz Game
description:
Wizard of Oz is an electronic game where players try to collect ruby slippers by traveling around the game board. A player landing on a space depicting film characters (Dorothy and Glinda for example) presses down on the Yellow Brick Road speaker. If the voice of a character depicted on the space speaks, the player receives a Ruby Slipper card. If it’s a character not depicted, the player's turn ends. If the voice is the Wicked Witch of the West, the player is sent to her castle.

A player with 3 or 4 Ruby Slipper cards may attempt to win by moving to a "Ruby Slippers Tapping" space. The player places the slipper cards on any of the five spinner spaces. If the spinner lands on the slippers for three spins in a row (three taps), the player wins.
categories: Electronic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Lenny Henry's Stand-Up Comic Game
description:
The object of the game is to be the first player to end up in the center of the spiral board track and be named "Star of the Show" with comic Lenny Henry.

In order to travel along the track, the player rolls a die and moves forward that number of spaces. If he ends up on a joke track, he rolls the die again and tells a joke of one of the following 6 types:


Knock-Knock
News Flash
Limerick
Riddles
Impersonations
Tongue Twisters


If the player cannot think of a joke of the type rolled, he can look at one of the many Joke Cards that comes with the game. (These all seem to be "G" rated and many are very UK-oriented.)

After telling a joke, the player rolls the die again to get a base score. This score will be modified by certain attributes pertaining to his joke telling, which include whether he used his own joke and how a vote of the other players goes. The player then moves forward a number of spaces equal to his revised score (or backwards if his score ends up negative). His turn continues until he lands on a non-joke space.

These other spaces involve drawing event cards that give directions to be followed and some "Chutes and Ladders" type spaces.

The first player to end up in the center space by exact movement wins.
categories: Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling, Voting

name: Chessmate
description:
From the box:

Chessmate is a new chess game which you can play using cards, instead of chess pieces. There are many similarities between chessmate and international chess but with chessmate, up to 6 players can play simultaneously. It has the intrigue of bridge, the chance of poker and the strategy of chess.

name: All American Football
description:
This is an old Parker Brothers game that simulates College Football. It comes with a board depicting a football field with a marker to show the balls location, and cards that showed play results. The player on Offense calls out one of the plays that the game allows - Off Tackle, Trick Play, Short Pass, Drop Kick (this was the 1920s), etc. The Defensive player then turns over the top card of the deck, reads the result of the play called, and moves the football marker on the game board.

Although it is a simple game, it does have the basic mechanics of a modern football board game. The main difference is that the player on Defense does not also call a play to match up with play called by the Offensive player before the results are determined.

name: Bambi
description: Based on the Disney movie, this is a simple 2 player race game with one player moving Bambi and the other moving Thumper. A spinner is used to determine a random color. Then a dial is turned clockwise to the same color spun revealing a picture in a window. If Bambi or Thumper is revealed, the respective player moves one space. If they are running, two spaces are moved. If both characters are shown, the player that is behind moves their pawn to the space occupied by the leader. Shortcut spaces help speed the players along. The winner is the first player to "jump the log" and land on a win space. In the advanced game, the winner is the first player to collect 4 Clover Pieces, either by dialing one in the window or by landing on a clover space. In this version, the players may have to circle the board several times before a winner is determined.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Domosolo
description:
You have 15 tiles, each tile divided in two with a color, and you have to place them in a square so that you have everywhere a line of three matching colors.
To make it even worse, you can place little tile-colors underneath and the tile above it, must have the same color.
Some sort of patience game with dominoes.

name: Bozo
description: This game has a board on which are mounted seven interlocking gears. To begin, you take Picture Disks (depicting Bozo and his friends) and place them on the faces of the gears. On your turn, you spin the spinner and rotate the center gear a number of notches equal to the number spun. You then check all the disks to see if any figures are standing on their heads (upside-down). If there are, you remove and keep them, replacing them with new discs from the stack. The player with the most discs, when they've all been removed, is the winner.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Money-maker
description:
An European version of Monopoly. You have a car and drive around the board (European cities instead of streets). You can buy them or buy petrol-stations (instead of railway-stations). You can buy drive-in restaurants (instead of houses) or motels (yes, indeed...).
The Service and All-Risk-cards are in four languages (English, French, German and of course Dutch for it's a game from Holland).
Winner is he who has all the money and properties, or he who has the most after a certain agreed time.

name: Superstore Challenge
description:
The object of the game is to use a strategy that will allow a player to gain the largest profits by the end of the game. Throughout the game players have the opportunity to purchase departments, companies and stores of varied sizes and payoffs to enable them to reach that goal.

Contains: Game board, die, 4 pencils, 6 player pawns, money, 70 department cards, 20 store cards, 10 company cards, 25 customer complaint cards, 25 supermarket cards and 1 pad of owner's stat sheets.

name: Huckleberry Hound
description: Players must race around the board to pick up and deliver a telegram while avoiding a nasty bulldog. On their turn, players move their Huckleberry Hound counter (in either direction along the path) and the Bulldog (presumably toward their opponents) according to the spin of a spinner. If the mean dog lands on you, you are sent back several spaces unless you have a bone or steak card. First to complete the circuit is the winner.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Over the Trenches
description: From the introduction: "This game is a variant on Risk; the world conquest game by Parker Brothers. Game play is similar, though you will find that with the new World War One game maps, use of Trench units, and a unique flavor of its own. Our goal in bring this game to you was to provide a strategy board game with the simplicity of play of Risk, but the more in depth strategic elements common in more complicated war games.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Set Collection

name: Cootie Jitterbug
description:
This is a dexterity game for children that uses a large motorized Cootie with holes in its shell. This Cootie Jitterbug is placed on the floor and plastic Cootie balls are scattered around it. Everyone chooses a different colored Cootie catcher that matches 3 of the Cootie balls. When everyone is ready, the Cootie Jitterbug is turned on by pressing its tail and it begins to wiggle and jiggle around.

Quick as they can, players use their Cootie collectors to "snap" up Cootie balls and then drop the balls into a hole on the Cootie Jitterbug's shell. Players must hurry since the Jitterbug will pop the balls back out almost as fast as they put them in. The first one to stop Cootie Jitterbug when all 3 matching Cootie balls are in wins the game.

name: The Curious George Game
description: This game is based on the Curious George books. Each player takes 7 balloon counters of 1 color, and uses a spinner to advance around the board. The spaces show many of Curious George's adventures. When you land on an Adventure Space, you place 1 of your balloon counters onto the white circle adjacent to it, but only if your color is not already on top of the pile of counters. If you land on a Corner Space, the player whose color matches the corner may place a balloon on any white circle that does not already have his or her color on top. The game stops when someone has placed all 7 balloons onto Adventure Spaces. Each player then takes all piles of balloons with his or her color on top. The player with the most balloons wins.

name: Dinosaur Island
description: In this game, players take on the roles of photographers who travel to recently discovered Dinosaur Island in an effort to take pictures that prove that dinosaurs still exist. Players roll dice to move their pawns along the island's jungle trails. If you land on a Star Space, you draw a card from the nearest stack. Cards might send you to a certain location, be used to thwart your opponents, or represent photographs. Photos can show nothing but foliage, part of a dinosaur, or an entire dinosaur. They have point values from 1 to 5 and the more dinosaur in the picture, the better the point value. When all the card stacks are depleted, the player with highest total points wins the game.

name: Beautiful
description:
Game inspired by the famous soap opera, it is basically a trivia with only a minor part of the questions related to the soap. Other questions regards health and beauty, fashion, high society's behavior. The first part of the game is a chip-gathering (representing Sally, Ridge, Stephanie and Brooke), while the last part are questions on the pre 1994 events in the soap.
Questions of the Italian edition seem to be (not so well) translated from English, so there must be an English version of the game.

name: Wuzzles Card Game
description: The object of this game is to try to collect 3 matching cards and play them so you can move your pawn ahead on the game path towards the Finish space. On your turn, you collect cards in two ways: by asking players for cards you need, and by taking cards from the draw pile.

name: The Curse of Tutankhamun
description:
This independently published game was sold in conjunction with the exhibition of King Tut's treasures that toured the United States in the late 1970's.

Packaged in a cardboard poster tube, the game consists of a laminated mapsheet, six plastic pawns, a set of 27 cards, and a standard six-sided die. The object of this roll-and-move game is to be the first player to reach King Tut's mummy in the burial room of his tomb. As described in the rules, "the game is one of twists of fate, some skillful play, and amusing excitement."

The publisher (The Prince and The Pirate Co.) is listed on the back of the rulebook as a "P.J. Bennett Enterprise" - possibly indicating the name of the designer?
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Lose a Turn, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Square Grid, Track Movement
publishers: The Prince and The Pirate Co.

name: Kaufhaus-Klau
description: The playing board is an abstracted department store, depicted by a three by three grid of rooms with walls and doorways between them. Each of the nine rooms in turn is divided into four by four. Ten wooden pieces represent customers who are trying to steal goods and two wooden pieces represent detectives who are trying to apprehend them. Also included are 24 goods pieces with hidden values and 1d6.

name: Window Shopping
description:
The game master secretly creates a picture using the cutouts provided. Players score for points for each element each one can recall from memory. The player with the most points after two rounds plays the prize round. The player is the prize round gets one second for every point of the winning score to recall as many prizes as possible. Each prize recalled is worth one prize point.

The player with most prize points after two games is the winner.

The game is a faithful adaptation of an obscure television show.

name: Every Man to His Station
description: Every Man to his Station was first published as a hand colored engraving in 1825 by Edward Wallis of London. Every Man to his Station has a moral theme illustrated with scenes from everyday country life. There are severe penalties imposed for bad behavior, notably being sent to the House of Correction, and for such misdemeanors as slothful behavior and theft. Rewards are given for charity, hardship, poverty and modesty. The instructions are charmingly written in rhyming verse and explore early nineteenth century life from the perspective of its morality ad social structures. Every Man to his Station is one of a set of collectible early nineteenth century boardgames from the archives of the Victoria and Albert museum, and this game is licensed 1994 for publication by the board of trustees of the V&A, published by the Historical Games Company, and is an exact duplication of one of the original surviving 1825 games on display at the museum. A gorgeous social historical piece as well as an insight into life almost 200 years ago

name: Combinato
description: A mastermind-type deduction game. It is advertised as two games in one: a word-deduction game and a number-deduction game.

name: Tigerkatze
description:
Children's game designed by Wolfgang Hund for Haba in the Simsala series. Ages 6 and up

6 wooden disks show the dice points with a kitten or a tiger on the reverse. With a wooden die, a simple roll and take the matching disk mechanic, trying to avoid the tiger.

An extra dice is included along with a selection of magic tricks that can be performed using the same game pieces.

name: Rainy Day Golf
description:
[From the back of the Box]
The Golf Game designed with the non-golfer in mind, yet so realistic that a golfer has the feeling of actually playing on a golf course. The instructions will not teach you to play golf, but in a matter of a few moments you will be a "pro" at playing "Rainy Day Golf."

Ages 10 and up

name: Jag vill ta körkort
description:
In Jag vill ta körkort, each player moves his vehicle according to his dice rolls about the game board while paying attention to the traffic rules. When his vehicle lands on a colored space, the player has to draw a card and answer the question on the card. Correct answers are rewarded with points. The first player to score 20 points wins the game and gets his driving license.

Jag vill ta körkort was published in conjunction with Sweden transitioning from left-hand traffic to right-hand traffic in 1967.

name: Skogsspelet
description:
Swedish trivia game.

Contents:
- Game board
- 6 pawns
- 3 different dice
- 500 question cards
- 25 price cards

name: Lobby
description:
This is probably the earliest game based on the U.S. legislative process. The mechanics are simple roll-and-move, but the game board gives players a detailed look at the many steps a bill must take between being introduced and being signed into law.

Each player starts by sponsoring a bill in either the Senate or House, and is encouraged to declare the subject and intent of the bill aloud for flavor. It then wends its way, 2D6 at a time, through obstacles such as committee hearings and filibusters, and when it succeeds in passing one chamber, it starts over in the other. After approval of both Senate and House, it makes its way 1D6 at a time toward final signing.

Players get one Parliamentary Procedure Card at game start, and may pick up Congressional Record cards along the way. Some of these have instructions (go forward or back x spaces), but others are "negotiable". Like the Parliamentary Procedure cards, these provide benefits like getting reported out of committee, ending an opponent's turn, ducking a filibuster and avoiding the deadly Red Circle spaces that kill your bill and send it back to start over. Players may trade such cards at any time.

The game is not as complex as the legislative process it models, but the descriptions on the spaces do provide a thorough review of just how complex that process is.

name: Henri Rochon Tennis à la Carte
description:
This is a card game version of tennis, based entirely on luck. The server draws from a service deck, if the ball is in play, the receiver draws a card from a play deck, and continues in that manner. Everything is highly abstracted, in that the type of shot doesn't matter beyond being in play or out. The one exception to this is that if the receiver of the service draws a return card of 'volley' or 'overhead' s/he has failed to return service. The game comes in a small box with rules, 20 service cards, 32 play cards, and score keeping sheets.

If you're wondering, Henri Rochon was a Canadian tennis player whose great claim to fame was apparently to have played at Wimbledon in 1952 before an audience of 25,000.

name: Clout!
description: The object of the game is to amass enough CLOUT at the grass roots level to give you the power and skill to gain support of the three highest levels of government; the White House, Congress and the Government Agencies

name: The California Raisins Card Game
description: A memory matching game with a California Raisins theme.

name: W.I.T.C.H. kortspel
description:
W.I.T.C.H. kortspel ("card game" in Swedish) is a card game based on the Disney comic W.I.T.C.H.

Each turn, a player chooses between drawing a card from the pile of cards not yet drawn, or giving a card to the player next in turn. Cards drawn are placed in front of the player, without looking on the back side. A player that is given a card by the previous player has to draw a card, they can't give one away.

Most cards have a score on the front face (visible to the person in turn), while a few others are scrying cards. The scrying cards allow the player to turn one card over to read the prophecy there. The card is then left with the back up, and this gives that card a new score. The prophecy text is about characters in the comic, and has nothing to do with the game play.

Only one card can be turned for a player at one time, so if you get the option to turn another one over, you must first decide if you want to flip the reversed card you may have back, before turning over a new one.

The player with the highest score when the deck runs out wins.

Contents:
- 32 cards.
- Rules (one card).

name: Cache-cache à la ferme de Foin-Foin
description:
A children's game Ages 4 and up where one must match animals in order to bring them into their pens. On your turn you roll, move to a square and turn over a disc from the field without showing it to other players. If they match you move the disc, face up, to your farm. You need to get 1 of each animal, 9 total, finishing with Rusty the dog.

English Name: "Hide and Seek at the Friendly Farm"
Website: www.gladius.ca

name: The Lifestyle Game: Knowledge Deluxe
description: A trivia game based on life style, fashion, design, art, wine, food, international trade, travel and luxury questions

name: Goosebumps: Cool Ghoul Action Card Game
description: The object of this Goosebumps themed game is to get rid of all your cards. The cards are dealt out evenly to all the players and kept face down. On your turn, you flip over your top card into the middle of the table. The cards feature Goosebumps characters and all players must simultaneously respond to the picture of the card just flipped such as: The Werewolf--tilt your head back and howl, Slappy--the last player to slap the pile takes the pile, Mud Monster--hold your nose, The Horror--do nothing. If all players do the right thing, the next player flips his or her card onto the pile. If someone goofs, that player takes all the cards on the table. Get rid of your stack of cards first and you win.

name: Political Assets
description:
Heavily inspired by Monopoly (Roll/move, land on properties which you can buy, etc.), in Political Assets players attempt to accumulate wealth and public opinion in a bid to become President. From the game summary:

"The object of Political Assets is to rise from the ranks of an everyday taxpayer to become President of the United States...to win the game you must own all the property (wealth) and accumulate 60% of the public opinion.

"The game was designed to show that in politics one must strive to move by attaining property and public opinion. It must be noted that in being to quick the person may become bankrupt or impeached from the group. On the other hand, if too slow another person will beat you to your goal. You may also make deals as well as most politicians do, however, please keep the deals related to both sides all inclusive to the game components only."

name: Norgesspillet
description: Trivia game on Norway. Visit and answer questions on different parts of the country.

name: Walt Disney's Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs Gigantik Game
description:
From the back of the box: Heigh-ho! Heigh-ho! It's off on a Snow White adventure you'll go! Work as a team, locating and helping the Seven Dwarfs clear the forest glade of the wicked Queen's poison apples!
Snow White is the fairest in the land. It's your Gigantik (R) task to prevent snow White from biting into a poisoned fruit and falling into an eternal sleep.
Players join all your favorite characters; Bashful, Doc, Sleepy, Grumpy, Sneezy, Happy, and Dopey, but beware the evil Queen's magic mirror. The player that collects the most poisoned apples wins the game.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Official Tabletop Football League Game
description:
Remember folding up a piece of paper into a small, triangular football shape, and then scooting that back and forth (with the occasional Field Goal) across the Cafeteria table in School? Well, this is the official packaging of that into a serious gaming entity!

This has it all! There are: two Field Goals (of the modern kind, and not the ole H-types) of plastic material, with separate, detachable suction-cup bases to temporarily adhere those to the tabletop; two Official foam Footballs-(of the proper size) with printing of the logo on one side, and strings for the pigskin on the reverse; one Official Rules Booklet (around 16 pages in length); one Touchdown Marker, and 20-Yards denoting with this also; one Official Scoreboard and Time Keeper (Time is actually kept by the score - agreed upon before commencing play, with a Halftime taking place when half of the Score is reached); and one Official Penalty Flag of actual cloth material! All of this, is contained within a nicely constructed BOX about 2 1/2 inches deep, 6 1/2 inches wide, and 10 1/2 inches long. There is even a Tournament of Champions page within the Rules Booklet, to record any epic events that are noteworthy, for anyone's use of this function -but, I'd recommend making a copy of this, in order to preserve the original page.

name: Kanga-Banga Roo
description: This simple children's game probably falls into the "Gnip Gnop" branch of the gaming tree. The object is to make your baby 'Roos hop to the top first. The game has a circular base into which 3 hoops (half hoops actually that are wicket shaped with flat tops) are inserted, each containing a 'Roo for each player (orange and purple). On both player sides, at the base of each hoop, is a paddle. On your turn, you strike a paddle and launch a 'Roo up the hoop where it hopefully stays on the top. You also try to knock your opponents 'Roos back down the hoops. Turns alternate between players. The first player to get all 3 of his 'Roos on top of the hoops wins the round. Two out of three rounds wins the game.

name: Bli kung i Baren
description: Based on Swedish reality show on TV3. In this game the players try to run a bar and avoid getting voted out.

name: Monopoly: München
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from München, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Fifth Division: Soviet Coming from our Lost Territory
description:
SGB-26 Fifth Division (1987) (JPY 4800)

Subtitled “Self Defense Force Series-03” and “Soviet Coming from our Lost Territory”.

One map, 504 counters, four PACs, a Series Rulebook (12 pages) and an Exclusive Rulebook (32 pages). There looks to be two scenarios.

Unit sizes are companies for the Japanese and US units, while the Soviets are all battalions. Turns are six hours, but the game may run for 13 days now.

name: Last Out
description:
Last Out is an electronic board that features rows of lighted buttons. These are in a stretched hexagon shape with 4 buttons in the outer rows, 5 buttons in the inner rows, and 6 buttons in the center row. On your turn, you press as many buttons in a single row (oriented in any direction of the hex) as you wish. When you press a button, it will flash showing your selection. When you are satisfied with your choices, you press the "GO" button and all your selected lights turn off. To win, you must force your opponent to turn off the last light. In other words, Last Out You Lose.

Other games limit the number of buttons you may press. You may play against a friend or the computer. The computer also has 48 preprogrammed puzzles to solve.

name: The Little Engine That Could
description: In this game, based on the famous children's story, you want to be the first player to make three trips over the mountain and deliver your toys, one at a time, to the children in town. Players all move the same Little Engine piece across the board. On your turn, you spin the spinner and advance the Little Engine to the next color space spun. If you spin the color matching your toys, you take another turn. Once the Engine reaches the mountain spaces marked "I think I can", players must then spin a color marked "I think I can" on the spinner to move the Little Engine any further. If at any time you spin the space marked "I thought I could!" you move the Little Engine, no matter where it is, all the way to town. If you are the player that moves the engine into town, you place one of your toy tokens, on the town space. The Engine is then placed back on the Start space and begins its next run. Be the first player to deliver your three toys to the town and you win the game.

name: Dino Builders
description: Dino Builders is a quick dice game with 3-dimensional dinosaurs. Each dino, when built, stands on its own, so there are plenty of possibilities for pretend play. Each part of the dinosaurs are numbered. Children collect the parts by rolling the die.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Set Collection

name: The Little Mermaid Undersea Princess Game
description: Be the first to find the hidden jewels and become the undersea princess. Hidden inside Ariel's musical clam carousel are the Princess' jewels. Young players look for matching colored jewelry. Older players roll the die to find the jewelry they need. Find three that match and you win.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Electronic, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: Doc et Difool
description: Based on French radio show.

name: Fairyland Adventure
description:
Simple Children's game based on Shirley Barber's Fairies.

Object of the game: To be the first to reach Fairyland.

Mechanic: Role and move your piece the indicated number of spaces. Game board is mostly non-directional allowing pieces to move in any direction.

Gameplay: You must move around the board collecting your 7 tokens first by landing on the correct squares. Then you obtain your magic ring by moving to the entrance to Fairyland and finally you receive an invitation into fairyland.

Magic cards and a Spinner add to the randomness of the game.

name: Sisyphos
description:
The task sounds simple: Push a few pieces forward to the finish line. But on the way there a few pitfalls... and already another piece has disappeared! In Sisyphos, players carefully and strategically move their pieces to try and earn the most points.

To setup, place stones on the start area of the gameboard. Each player takes 3 cards from their stack to form their hand. Players play cards to move their stones on the board. The player with the most points wins.

name: Daytonopoly
description: You start out the game as a visitor to our fair community. By acquiring various properties such as local hotels, restaurants, retail stores, radio stations, TV stations and other well-known businesses in the areas- and developing them into skyscrapers- you become a resident entrepreneur. The last entrepreneur to avoid bankruptcy, or the one with the most property, wins! It's just a different version of monopoly.

name: Throw Up
description:
According to the publisher, "It's loud, it's ludicrous, it's brilliant. THROW UP is the appallingly funny NEW game for two or more. Get your wits in gear or suffer the consequences"

THROW UP is usually played as a drinking game (rule 1: "Ensure that you have a ready supply of liquid refreshments"). The game begins as a rhythmic word game. Players tap the table and clap in rhythm. The first player calls out a word and the player to his/her left shouts out a word that begins with the final letter of the first word (e.g., word 1 = "cat", word 2 = "ten", word 3 = "naked"...). Players who cannot think of a word, break the rhythm, or who make a mistake must roll a pewter die (it is in the form of a drunk; it reminds me of the pigs in "Pass the Pigs") to determine a penalty.

The position of the die determines the penalty:
? A choker: take a large swallow.
? A sticky ear (bottle up): you and the player to your left take a large swallow.
? A sticky ear (fish up): you and the player to your right take a large swallow.
? A gutter: choose one of the other players to take a large swallow.
? A dribbler: propose a toast; everyone takes a drink.
? A tumble: Off the table, finish your glass.

The game includes:
? 1 Pewter drunk figure
? 1 pen
? 1 forfeit pad
? 1 forfeit summary card
? 1 carry pouch
? 1 set of rules
categories: Action / Dexterity, Dice, Humor, Party Game, Word Game

name: The Battle of Trafalgar 1805
description: The Battle of Trafalgar 1805 board game celebrates the 200th anniversary of the famous encounter between the combined fleets of Napoleonic France and her ally, Spain, against the British fleet commanded by Admiral Horatio Nelson on the 21st of October 1805. The game contains miniature ships of the line to give the realistic appearance of two fleets of "Men 'O' War" engaging in battle.

name: Tops and Tails
description:
From the box:

Rules for Several Players:

Shuffle the cards well, and deal them out equally, face downwards. If any player finds he has a complete matching picture in his hand he can lay it down immediately, face upwards. Matching halves bear the same number.
The player on the right of the dealer begins by laying one card down, face upwards. If the next player has the card to match it, he puts it down and takes the complete picture, counting it as a set in his favor. If he has not got the matching card he can put down any other card to make whatever funny combination he likes. However, only a "top" can be laid to a "tail", or vice versa, as two tops or two tails cannot be put together. If a player has not the type of card required, he loses his turn to the next player. The winner is the player with most complete sets at the end of the game.

Rules for One Player:

Shuffle the cards well and lay them out face downwards in pairs, in such a way that the design on the backs of each pair forms a complete picture. Then turn the cards face upwards one by one. The resulting comical combinations will give a lot of amusement. If any of the pairs of cards you have laid out forms a matching pair (a set), place them on one side, face upwards, then shuffle the remaining cards and repeat the process until all the matching pairs have been found.
You can take as long as an hour to play this game, and will always get different combinations.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Pattern Building, Set Collection

name: Men Behaving Badly
description:
'Mellow out with the top game for blokes on totty'

Move around the board picking up action or Trivia cards.

name: Mr. Ribbit's Pond
description: This game features Mr. Ribbit, an electronic plastic frog who sits on a large central lily pad. Nine smaller lily pads are placed in a circle around it. The small pads have a picture of either a bug or a gator on their bottoms. On your turn, you pick up Mr. Ribbit and place him on any small lily pad. If he says "Sproing!", hop him to the next lily pad and so on around the circle. When he's through "sproinging", he will say "Rrribbit! Who's there?" You must then guess if the lily pad he's on has a bug or a gator underneath. If you guess correctly, you keep the lily pad. If Mr, Ribbit says "Splash!", move him to any lily pad of your choice. The first player to collect 3 lily pads is the winner. A second game may be played where players collect bug tokens instead of lily pads.

name: Alton Metropoly
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

This is a game like Monopoly, but centers around Alton, IL.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Affton Opoly
description: This is a game like Monopoly, but centers around Affton, MO. Includes game board, fate & chamber cards, property cards, play money, green and red discs, 4 tokens and 2 dice, and original instructions.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Centipede: A Cardcade Game
description: This is a card game for Ages 5 and up based on the famous Atari Centipede video game. The game consists of 56 cards that differ in (1) background color, (2) insect, and (3) number. Players play cards as quickly as they can. Each card played must match the top card on one of the two play piles on one of the three variables. The first person to play all his or her cards earns a centipede section. The first person to win three pieces wins the game.

name: Space Bug
description: Roll a die and put a peg in your space bug, until all the pegs are in place. Each number on the die is associated with a particular body part on the bug.

name: Hugo: The Game
description:
Subtitled "The Wild and Windy Game of Survival". Hurricane Hugo strikes, and the players move around the board trying to reclaim insurance adjustments, find their lost dog, and so on. The system is a straightforward roll-and-move system, with certain spaces having set effects and other spaces having you draw from either a deck of harmful cards (which take your money) or a deck of beneficial cards (which give you money). The one with the most money after everyone reaches the Finish space is the winner.

From the rules:
"Each player is the proud owner of two homes - one beach house and one primary residence; two cars - a Volvo wagon and a BMW; a black Labrador named 'Stud'; $100,000 in stocks and cash. Net worth of each individual is $500,000."

Half of the single rules sheet is a historic description of Hurricane Hugo's devastation. The game itself is darkly humorous.

name: U.S.A. Bicentennial Game
description:
"An enjoyable game for Americans of all ages."

Players roll and move around a board decorated with photographs of American icons (e.g., the Statue of Liberty). Each space has a number. Land on the space, select a category card, and attempt to answer the corresponding trivia question. The difficulty of the questions varies widely. The more difficult the question, the more stars it is worth. The first player to earn 50 stars wins the game.

name: Helicopter Race Game
description:
This game by Warren Paper Products Company was released sometime in the 50's and was capitalizing on children's fascination with a relatively new mode of transportation - the helicopter. The players race along a track spanning a map of the US, starting in California, hitting the Atlantic seaboard, and then racing back to California for the exciting finish.

Movement is controlled with a spinner. Pieces include a game board, 4 tokens of different colors that look like a head and shoulders, a spinner, a card board holder for the bits, and the box top and bottom. Instructions for the game are on the board.

name: Capital Hill
description:
"Capital Hill", as the title suggests, is a game of accumulating money through the political process. In the regular version, three to six players start with a randomly determined number of chips representing Senators and members of the House of Representatives. Each player directs their politicians to gain power and money by winning elections, holding onto power positions, and passing laws. Players are eliminated when they lose all their representation in the House and Senate. When only two players remain, the player with the most money is declared the winner.

A short version permits two to six players to compete for a fixed number of game rounds; again, the player with the most money at the end is the winner.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Praise the Loot???
description:
"Praise the Loot???" is a product of the mid-1980s, when at least one prominent televangelist was found using his fun raising abilities for somewhat less than evangelical goals. In this game, 2-6 players race to the Pearly Gates. However, instead of amassing virtues - or even converts - the victor must acquire sufficient money and possessions in order to win.

Includes 6 playing pieces, one die, 6 different denominations of money ($5,000 to $500,000), 3 types of cards (possession, contribution and expense), instructions and fold out board (14" X 19.5").
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Sailboat Race Game
description: Simple roll and move game for boys and girls Ages 4 - 8
publishers: Built-Rite, Tee Pee Toys, Jessup Paper Box Co.

name: Bacchus
description:
From the box :

Quiz game about wine!

Bacchus is an educational game. This games was designed to be fun and at the same time teach wine-lovers more about the wonderful world of wine.
Remember: wine is not only an experience for the senses and the spirit but also a pleasure and a pastime.

name: Reise-Quiz
description: Questions about geography in German.

name: Double Your Money
description:
Double Your Money is a board game from the 1950's, produced by Bell games and based on the very successful UK ITV game show of the same name hosted by Hughie Green.

The board has 4 distinct triangles. Each triangle reflects the player's colour - Green, Red, Blue or Yellow. Each player place themselves at the start of their chosen colour. No two players can be in the same triangle. Movement is decided by the spinner in the centre of the board. A player moves along each row of their triangle. If a player's piece lands on the same colour square as his colour, he is asked a question. If he is right, he places his marker to the side of his triangle in the first prize money of 1 pound. Next time he gets a question right, he will double his money i.e. a progression of 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, etc. (except when the prize money gets to 256 pounds, when it next jumps to 500 pounds so that the prize money could stop at 1,000 pounds.
The first player to gain the prize of 1,000 pounds is the winner.

The TV show, in its day, was extremely popular. Anyone winning the thousand pound prize was a celebrity (it didn't happen a lot). A thousand pounds, in the austerity of 1950's Britain, was a great deal of money.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Barbie Sparkle Kingdom Game
description:
The Barbie Sparkle Kingdom game is very much like a Barbie themed Candyland. Rather than drawing cards with colors on them, the player spins a spinner, chooses a flower on the spinner, looks under the flower for the color and moves their piece to the next space on the board of that color. If that space has a flower, the player gets another turn. If the player lands on a bumble bee, they have to go back to the spot of the previous bumble bee on the board. There are short cuts (Rainbow Bridge, Butterfly Trail, Crystal Path) to speed you along your route. The winner is the player to be the first to Barbie's Jeweled Palace.

Components:
1 glittery game board
4 Barbie playing pieces
1 flower spinner with base
5 plastic flowers
50 glittery stickers
1 spinner and playing piece label sheet
Instructions

name: Titanic Trivia
description: The Titanic Trivia Board game includes 1000 questions tastefully presented in four levels: Novice, Cruiser, Buff and Historian. Players will be asked critical facts about the building of the ship, the ship's decor, the journey, the crew, the tragedy, and the aftermath. Participants from the casual movie viewer to the hard core historian will thoroughly enjoy this exciting game.

name: Whickers World
description:
A Family game for 2-6 players themed loosely around the TV Series Whickers World.

Components:

Gameboard
250 Question Cards (2000 questions)
Dice
Counters
Rules

Players move round the board through a combination of dice throws and answering questions from the cards.

During his turn a player earns the right to move any of his or her four counters by correctly answering the first question (of 6) on a card - this question normally refers to a picture on the reverse of the card.

The distance moved is determined by dice roll - this roll also being used to determine the number of the next question to be answered (from the same card). If the player answers the question correctly they may roll the dice again and have another question asked (from the same card). Play continues in this manner until a question is answered incorrectly or the same number is rolled twice on that particular card. It is then the next player's turn.

Movement is also influenced by certain of the cards and instructions written on the board.

There is also an element of tactical play in that landing one of your counters on the same square as another player's counter you send that counter back to that player's start point.

The winner is the first player to take all of their four counters around the world (the board) from their start to their finish point.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Travel, Trivia

name: Road Block
description:
From the Publisher:

Here's a great game that introduces map reading skills and following directions. Players mover around the gameboard and answer questions and set up "road blocks" to stop their opponents. Play money is included and when you reach your destination you receive $5. The first player to accumulate $30 wins!

name: The Necromancer's Bane
description:
The Necromancer's Bane is a set of wargames rules (22 pages) designed to reproduce large-scale battles set in a fantasy realm, be it Middle Earth, Hyboria or any other mythical setting. The rule set addresses scales from 6mm up to 25mm.

Two supplements are also available, one covering magicians and a more detailed handling of magic (14 pages), and the second addressing sieges in a fantasy environment (14 pages).

name: Pokémon Build 'n Battle
description: Pokemon Build 'n Battle combines model building with a simple dice driven combat system. Each kit contains lego-like blocks to build a pokemon and its evolved form, as well as a die, a card with statistics for the two forms and some extra blocks for keeping track of the pokemons' statistics. After enough wins, the player is allowed to use the evolved form of the pokemon.
categories: Collectible Components, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Video Game Theme

name: The Nitrate War
description:
A small board game covering the Nitrate War. The conflict between Chile and the alliance of Bolivia and Peru. Also represented in the game are Argentina and American Industrialists.

Game includes:
4 pages of rules
17" x 22" two piece map
150+ cut out counters
1D10
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: Jätinlinnan Ryöstö
description:
Jätinlinnan Ryöstö "Raid on Giants' Castle" boardgame came with Finnish translation of special themed Donald Duck pocket book number five Velhojen Valtakunta "Realm of Wizard", an fantasy special with familiar Disney character engaging in Lord of the Rings/sword & sorcery style fantasy adventures. Art of the gameboard comes from comic Taikamiekka (Magic Sword) drawn by Massimo De Vita.

Game itself is of simple roll and move variety, each player starts from one of the four villages pictured on the board, object is to get one of the keys of four different color, get to giants castle trough door of corresponding color, pick the magic sword and return to your starting location.

Board is made of thin cardboard and about 18x24 centimeters.
Players move around chits with four characters from the story printed on them, keys and other objects are also printed on the same kind of thin cardboard. Rules of the game are supplied on small sheet of glossy paper.

Game does not come with dice.

name: The Honey West Game
description:
The Honey West Game is subtitled "The Girl Private-Eye Game", and is based on the ABC TV series starring Anne Francis which aired 1965-1966.

Contents: One game board depicting a movement track with event squares
4 player pieces
Spinner
Honey West token Cards
Game Event Cards

Players spin and move round the track. As even squares are landed on, event cards are draw and resolved with the spinner, and Honey West Tokens are collected.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Spies/Secret Agents

name: Pig of a Game
description:
Pig of a game is a game in the 'big fun in a little box' series by Tobar Ltd. Like other games in the series, it comes in a large matchbox-like container and has nice miniature scoring pads and pencils. The main equipment are three pink six-sided dice, with the numerals 1,3,4,5,6 and a pig on the sides. like other members of the Pig family of dice games, it has a push-your-luck game mechanism.

From the instructions:

Pig of a game (2 or more players)

Before the game begins, each player throws one die once. The player throwing the highest number (pig = nil) begins the game.

The first player throws all three pig dice and adds the score on each face to produce a total for that throw. The player can then keep that score and pass the dice on to the next player or throw the dice again.

This process can continue until a winning score is accumulated. BUT if one pig is thrown, the round finishes and the total accumulated in preceding throws is added to the player's total. If two pigs are thrown, the round finishes and any score accumulated in the same round and prior to the offending throw is wiped out. If three pigs are thrown, the round finishes and any score accumulated in this and any previous round is wiped out.

The winner is the first player to attain a total of 101."

name: Egypt to Canaan No.3 The Ten Commandments
description: This simple roll and move game is one in a series of Bible games by the same publishers. The first player to make it from start to finish wins. Along the way each player must collect cards (the ten commandments) in order to advance.
mechanics: Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Brooklyn in a Box
description: A Monopoly clone from Late For The Sky; this version is based in Brooklyn, New York. It has spaces such as Flatbush Avenue, Mermaid Parade, The Boardwalk, New York Aquarium, Verrazano Narrows Bridge, and Coney Island. The tokens include Egg Cream, Hot Dog, Brooklyn Bridge, Deno's Wonder Wheel, Brooklyn Dodgers Cap, and a Heart. Cards include local events and staples of life in Brooklyn.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Charlotte in a Box
description: A Monopoly clone from Late For The Sky; this version is based in Charlotte, North Carolina. It has spaces such as Paramount's Carowinds, The Square, Charlotte Motor Speedway, South 21, Fourth Ward, Mint Museum, and Uptown. The tokens include a football, heart, basketball shoe, trolley car, crown, and a race car. Cards include local events and staples of life in Charlotte.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Strawberry Shortcake Card Game Pick-A-Basket
description:
Strawberry Shortcake is having a housewarming party. She'd love to receive fruit baskets as her surprise housewarming present. How many can you collect for her? Match as many Fruit Basket cards as you can. The one with the most Fruit Basket cards at the end of the game is the winner.

This is a matching game with a twist. Players place all their matches face up in one pile in front of them. If you can match a card to the card on top of their Fruit Basket pile, you can steal ALL their matches.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Strawberry Shortcake Card Game Double "Berry" Talk
description:
Everyone who knows about Strawberryland knows about the Berry Birds. They're the feathered friends of the Purple Pieman, and they repeat everything they hear! Be a Berry Bird by matching each of the Fruit cards that are played. Then use that fruit to make up your very own recipe. The one with the fewest Fruit cards at the end of the game is the winner.

This is a matching game like Uno but the only special card is a wild. If you cannot match a card on your turn, you add the entire discard pile to your hand. The game ends when there are no more cards in the draw pile.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Take Your Pick!
description: "Take Your Pick" is a board game from the 1950's, produced by Bell games and based on the very successful UK ITV game show of the same name hosted by Michael Miles.

name: Los Angeles in a Box
description: A Monopoly clone from Late For The Sky; this version is based in Los Angeles, California. It has spaces such as Watts Tower, Venice Beach, Farmer's Market, Hollywood, Dodger Stadium, Malibu, and the Walk of Fame. The tokens include a movie reel, cookie, surfboard, roller blade, sunglasses, and a sailboat. Cards include local events and staples of life in Los Angeles.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Parkology
description:
From the box: Parkology is an educational game designed to entertain the players. As you advance around the board you'll need to decide whether or not to build campsites at the Parks you land on. You'll discover ways to outsmart the other players as you determine when and where to build. But...watch out, the roll of the dice can make a big difference -- you may end up at Alcatraz! (Lost & Found is much more fun!) Good luck!

It looks like a Monopoly variant, but with some differences.
